header.topics: Moving into the area in the 1960s; coming for an interview to be a dentist (anecdote), finding somewhere to live after getting jobs in the area (dentist and teacher); accommodation in the 1960s: renting/buying/renovation (various anecdotes); where they met their wives; colleges attended; post graduate course (dentistry) - humorous story of trip for post graduate course at Athens university when the first day of the dictatorship occurred. Time change when travelling.
header.activity: Friends talking over a glass of wine: dentist and teachers - college days, careers and moving into a new area and finding accommodation

from wh sound proofing it was sound proofing because of course the the officers' boots you know

but they never actually took the concrete up again when they left so
bloody hell that must have been heavy

in part well yeah because it started to break up

but the kids our kids used to have parties up there and of course it was like so spooky
cos everyone thought it was a strange thing when I was drawing the plans up there was a discrepancy in the height of the rooms
cos I measured the outside of the building
and then measured the rooms inside and there was like five feet one and a half metres

the building outside was one and a half metres higher than the rooms inside and we couldn't work this out and then one day there was a fire actually was playing golf at and he saw smoke rising from his house

and we I tailed it back and sure enough there was a fire but the fire was coming up in our flat the the smoke was coming up in our flat we thought it's coming under the floorboards so I ripped a couple of floorboards up and there was this big void
one and a half metres deep

well in those days because the ceilings were so heavily moulded with plasterwork and whatever it was a suspended ceiling you couldn't have walked on the same joists that were holding the ceiling up because it would vibrate and the plaster would
crack off so they had separate joists for the floor upstairs than the joists holding the plasterwork ceiling
so you would only get that in big fancy houses you wouldn't get that in more simple
so you could hide all sorts of things there
you could you couldn't actually walk cos it was only one point five you couldn't walk along it but you could certainly sort of stoop and crawl along and whatever mm

we get if we go to Athens
we can have six days there
so is anybody up for that?
the only bloke from who went
but we met a load of people
no I'm not up for it? I can't imagine it
no I can't take the time I can't afford that no way oh I'm not going on a post graduate course
the only trouble was I forget which year it was but it was the year of one of the one of the er when the generals took over
and the first night we got there
this chap who was organising it he he'd he had been happily married in wh er four kids who were more or less grown up and he had a bit of an affair with a final year student
and he nursed her through her finals
I like that he nursed her through her finals
it it turned out we we and it yeah yeah anyway
we went we went on this this thing and he did actually he told me he said well actually I'm on my honeymoon so
said come on alright and he was in the room the bedroom next to us and during the night
I'm is is his going to survive?
anyway nenext morning we went down and th ter chaos the Americans had locked themselves in their rooms
there was this you know the generals had taken over
and we what we'd heard was tanks going through the streets
and they were still going the next morning and we looked out you know and they were going over cars it was very impressive see a tank goes over
goes over traffic lights and cars
meanwhile in the bedroom next door
oh god it was the end of the world
whereas we were you know dentists and we could well this there was a guard armed guard on the door but he was a nationalist serviceman who wanted to improve his Englishman er English

so he said well yeah just gonna you can walk up the street but don't don't go too far else you might get shot but of course you know they'd er and it was all really quite peaceful until we realised that the barman lived of the hotel lived the other side of Athens and couldn't get in to open the bar so we were knackered stuck in this hotel
they've written a song about that
there's nothing so morbid loathsome or drear than to stand at the bar of a pub with no beer
but dentists being dentists there's always there's a resourceful bloke
who can pick locks so the hotel manager said well that's fine he said if you can get it open he said that's fine just keep a tab and we had a fantastic time

the first two the first two days we weren't supposed to leave the hotel but we did and then after that it was sort of quite happening because the I think everybody realised it was going to be a better regime
